value.displayForm: This catalogue entry draws substantially on Paul Binski, Patrick Zutshi and Stella Panayotova, Western Illuminated Manuscripts: A Catalogue of the Collection in Cambridge University Library (Cambridge, 2011).

dataRevisions.displayForm: Arthur Westwell, Suzanne Paul, James Freeman
dataRevisions.label: Author(s) of the Record

abstract.displayForm:
A fourteenth-century English Book of Hours, according to the Sarum Rite, stunningly illustrated with several full-page saints' portraits opening the work and the main text accompanied by a dazzling flurry of borders, marginalia and initials. Some saints' names featuring in the calendar with which the book opens suggest that it may have been originally produced according to practice local to the East Midlands, perhaps Lincoln, but the additions made to the calendar very early on in its life locate it firmly in East Anglia, and particularly, perhaps, around Ely and Huntingdon. The names of owners, Alice de Reydon, and John and Matilda Stranle, with their birth and death dates added alongside those saints, tell a story of continual spiritual practice and personal devotion as it passed from hand to hand.

This item was included in the Library’s 600th anniversary exhibition Lines of Thought: Discoveries that changed the world.
abstract.label: Abstract

collation.displayForm:
The MS consists of 12 quires as follows:

1 modern paper flyleaf
Quire 16 (fols 1-6)
Quires 2-612 (fols 7-78)
Quire 710 (fols 79-88)
Quire 812 (2 leaves inserted after 6; fols 89-100)
Quire 9-10 10 (fols 101-120)
Quire 11 8 (fols 121-128)
Quire 126 (fols 129-135; wanting folios 136-8)
1 modern paper flyleaf
collation.label: Collation

value.displayForm: Generally superb condition, both of illumination and of script. Some staining on final three folios, 132v-135v. Parts of miniatures have been cut off in the binding process, see for example 54v-55r

16 lines.

Ruling is distinct in brown ink, throughout, except for on 75v-78r, where French prayers were added to presumably blank folios, but pricking is not visible anywhere.

The calendar, comprising folios 13r-18v is presented in four columns, comprising the dates, days of the week, and particular saints' days.

The remainder of the book is in one column.

Written in Gothic Textualis, generally by a single scribe.

However the prayers in French, on 75v-78r are added by two later hands, but the second hand only inscribes 78r

Folios 95r-96v written in a 16th-century hand.

Twelve full-page framed miniatures on tooled gold or diapered pink and blue ground, in pairs at alternating openings before Calendar:

1v woman kneeling before a sainted archbishop
2r St Catherine and St Margaret
3v St George
4r St Christopher
5v Annunciation
6r Nativity
7v Resurrection
8r Ascension
9v Coronation of Virgin
10r Christ in Majesty with Evangelists' symbols
11v Virgin and Child
12r Crucifixion


12v Rough drawing of St John the Baptist with Lamb, probably added in the 14th century.


Calendar miniatures depicting zodiac signs and occupations of months on punched gold ground under canopies, in outer margins:

13r Janus feasting, Aquarius (January)
13v man warming himself by fire, Pisces (February)
14r pruning, Aries (March)
14v hawking, Taurus (April)
15r Maying, Gemini (May)
15v mowing, Cancer (June)
16r reaping, Leo (July)
16v threshing, Virgo (August)
17r harvesting grapes, Libra (September)
17v sowing, Scorpio (October)
18r beating for acorns, Sagittarius (November)
18v slaughtering pig, Capricorn (December)


Historiated initials:

19r Woman praying to Virgin and Child on punched gold ground (9 lines, Matins)
79r Christ seated holding book and blessing on blue and red chequeboard ground (7 lines, Penitential Psalms)


Figural, ornamental and minor initials:

Initials (3-6 lines) filled with foliated and zoomorphic spirals, on tooled gold ground, to remaining Hours of Virgin (26v, 37v, 41r, 43v, 45v, 48r, 52r) and at beginning of Hours of Holy Spirit (68r)
blue Calendar initials (4 lines) with red and green foliage infill on gold ground
blue initials (2-7 lines) filled with foliage, human heads or grotesques on gold ground
alternating gold and blue one-line verse initials with blue and red penwork flourishes


Border decoration of rich foliage in blue, red, green and gold extending from letter finials and forming full or partial frames; heraldic shields with arms of England and Aymer de Valence, one shield effaced and three further shields to right cropped (19r); marginal grotesques and drolleries.


Linefillers of vegetation, geometric and zoomorphic designs in blue or turquoise and red, some forming frames.

Folio 1r has an additional prayer in French.

Under the illustration on 4r, a Latin collect has been added

On folios 61r-74r, the rubrics have been erased and written over in French.

Folios 95r-96v were added later, written in a 16th-century hand, presumably due to loss of these folios in the original.

Additions have been made to the calendar, 13r-18v, by several hands dating variously to the early fourteenth to the fifteenth century. These include obits and saints' days (see Provenance for further details) and notes by two hands that mark the beginning and end of the 'dies caniculares' (or 'dog days'; 16r, 17r), the hottest period of the year.
Full brown leather over wooden boards, marked as from 1962

Probably owned by Alice de Reydon, wife of Robert de Reydon, whose obituary is added to the Calendar in a contemporary hand, on the 5th July (fol. 16r), "Obitus Alicie de Reidon anno domini mccc..." but the rest of the date is cropped. The coat of arms of her own family, Reymes, also appear on fol. 19r, a cross engraved in gules inside initial V. Alice may be the donor depicted on 1v and 19r. In any case she was certainly deceased by 1323.

Two early or mid-fourteenth century hands have inserted additional feast days that confirm an East Anglian provenance: St Winwaloe ('Sancti Winewaloei') on 3rd March (14r) and St Ethelbert on 21st May (usually 20th; 15r). Winwaloe is more commonly patron saint of foundations in the south-west, his reputed homeland, however a Benedictine priory dedicated to him was founded at Wereham in 1199; it was later dissolved in 1321 and given to nearby abbey of West Dereham.

The manuscript was then owned by Stranle family: the birth dates of John Stranle (17th February) and Matilda Stranle (9th April) were inserted in the calendar by perhaps the same hand (13v, 14v). Another, later hand glossed the entry for John Stranle with the year of his birth: 'anno Regis Ricardi secundi quarto' (1380/81).

It is not known how or when the manuscript entered the University Library collection but it does appear in the catalogue written in 1754-6, now CUL MS Oo.7.53.

Yapp, W. Brunsdon, "The birds of English medieval manuscripts", Journal of Medieval History 5 315-349 (1979).
Harris-Matthews, J. M., Lay devotions in late medieval English manuscripts (M.Litt. thesis Cambridge: University of Cambridge, 1980).
